intro: Allium stearnianum subsp. vanense, commonly known as the Vanese leek, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It features basal rosettes of narrow, grass-like leaves and produces umbels of white to pale purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soils. It is closely related to other allium species and is often cultivated for its ornamental value. Its botanical characteristics make it a distinctive member of the Amaryllidaceae family.
